overview: The measure, HB72 SD1, has now been reviewed and passed by the Senate Committee on Commerce and Consumer Protection without further amendment (HB72_SD1_SSCR1642_). Widespread testimony submitted to the committee continues to express strong support for establishing a registration requirement for pharmacy technicians, citing the need to align with national standards and enhance patient safety (HB72_SD1_TESTIMONY_CPN_03-27-25_). The core components of the bill, including the registration start date of January 1, 2026, remain unchanged (HB72_SD1_SSCR1642_).
economic_impact: Further testimony from stakeholders, including major pharmacy chains like Walgreens and individual pharmacists, reinforces that the costs associated with registration are considered a 'reasonable cost' and a 'prudent investment' for ensuring public safety (HB72_SD1_TESTIMONY_CPN_03-27-25_). This broad support indicates an industry-wide acceptance of the financial impact of the registration requirement. The new testimony does not introduce any new cost figures or financial data (HB72_SD1_TESTIMONY_CPN_03-27-25_).
updates_from_previous_fiscal_note: The primary update is the measure's successful progression through the Senate Committee on Commerce and Consumer Protection, which recommended its passage without any new amendments (HB72_SD1_SSCR1642_). The financial and policy framework established in HB72 SD1, including the biennial registration fee and the 2050 sunset date, remains intact. The latest round of testimony confirms continued and broad-based support for the bill from various sectors of the pharmacy community, including the Board of Pharmacy, the University of Hawai ªi, and corporate pharmacies (HB72_SD1_TESTIMONY_CPN_03-27-25_).
